There’s no evidence to suggest that children with COVID-19 are more susceptible to severe illness than their non-custodial parents, according to a new study.

Researchers at the University of Minnesota found that the risk of developing serious illness among a single mother with two children and her two adult children living together was 2.6 times higher among those who had been separated than among the general population.


The study, which was published online March 27 in the journal Pediatrics, looked at data from more than 1,200 U.S. adults ages 18 to 44, who were randomly assigned to receive either the flu vaccine or a live attenuated strain of the coronavirus. The study participants were then asked to rate their health on a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being "extremely" (extremely bad) and 10 "not so bad," meaning that they had a "high likelihood of having the virus," the researchers found. Those who received flu shots were more likely to have a high-grade fever, sore throat, and shortness of breath, compared to people who did not receive the vaccine. But the children of those vaccinated fared worse on tests that measured immune function, such as a blood test that showed levels of IgG, a type of antibody that is produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes. And those children also had higher rates of type 2 diabetes, heart disease and lung disease, the study found, but those were not associated with any specific health problems.  
 “Children who are separated from their parents may be at higher risk for illness and poorer outcomes, including poorer mental health, poorer school performance and reduced access to care,” said Dr. Anthony Fauci, an expert in family medicine and public health at Harvard Medical School. Children born to mothers who have experienced a miscarriage or miscarriage should be cared for in a manner that minimizes their exposure to viruses, he said. They should also wash their hands frequently, avoid touching their eyes, nose and mouth, cover their cough with the bend of elbow or tissue and maintain a distance of at least 1 meter (3 feet) from others when they are ill, to help prevent respiratory droplets from reaching their lungs and to prevent them from spreading to others. If the mother and child are living in separate homes, they should stay at home if they have respiratory problems and avoid contact with anyone who is not their mother or child. In addition, pregnant women and their newborns should regularly clean and disinfect surfaces and surfaces with household disinfectants and hand sanitizers, as recommended by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. For more information about the risks and benefits of social distancing, visit the CDC website at https://www.cdc.gov/who-we-are/about-the-contraceptive-disinfection/2019-ncov/summary.cfm?CDC_COPYRIGHT_DEATHS_SIR_COVID_19_NCOV_01_03.pdf and CDC Tips for Pregnant Women and Children on How to Protect Yourself and Your baby from the 2019-nCoV. Learn more about how your health and well-being can be improved by self-isolation and hand hygiene during pregnancy and childbirth.<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

There’s currently no evidence to suggest that using antiretrovirals (e.g. ibuprofen, naproxen, etc.) is associated with increased risk of serious illness or death. However, the World Health Organization (WHO) has advised against the use of any form of antiviral medicine, including corticosteroids, as a means of preventing, treating, and preventing infection.  However, there are some indications that some types of medicines may be effective against some infections. For more information on the safety and effectiveness of certain medicines, see WHO Guidance for Allergy and Asthma and How to Use Antiviral Medicine. Learn more about how your health care provider can protect you and protect the health and well-being of others.<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

I am currently a PhD student in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Waterloo.

I have been working on a project to test the viability of a novel coronavirus vaccine for COVID-19. The vaccine has been approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for use in humans and is being tested on animals. Currently, there is no human clinical trial underway to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the vaccine. However, I would like to use this opportunity to ask a few questions:


What is the current state of research on human trials of human-virus vaccines? 
Is there a vaccine candidate that can be used to prevent or cure the disease, and how long will it be effective against the virus? What are the clinical trials that would determine whether or not this vaccine is safe and effective for human use? (For example, if the human trial is successful, would it have a significant benefit in preventing or treating the common cold?)
Are there any vaccine candidates that are currently under development that could be safely and effectively used for the treatment or prevention of diseases such as cancer, HIV, diabetes, or other chronic diseases? Are there vaccines or therapeutics that have the potential to treat or prevent some of these diseases, but which are not yet widely used in clinical settings (e.g. cancer vaccines)?
Can I safely use a human test kit to measure the effectiveness of an effective human vaccine against a disease? If so, what are some potential clinical advantages and disadvantages of using human tests for diagnosing and treating diseases in animals, including the risk of false positive results, false negatives, side effects, etc.?
If not, why not use animal testing for disease prevention, rather than human testing to identify and treat diseases that may be causing us to be ill?

The current outbreak in Wuhan, China, is thought to be the result of human-to-animal transmission. However, there is no evidence to suggest that this is the case in humans. 

In the context of the current pandemic, it is important to distinguish between the two. The WHO has advised against the use of hand sanitizer in contact with animals, and the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) has banned the importation of raw meat and animal products from countries with confirmed or suspected links to the 2019-nCoV outbreak. In addition, the WHO recommends that all travellers to and from China be advised to wash their hands thoroughly with soap and water for at least 20 seconds before entering the country, as this may increase the risk of catching the virus.


https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronaviruses/2019-ncov/summary-of-the-current-surveillance-report-on-covid19-infection-in-chinese-people/article/S00382-1048(20)30161-3
  The World Health Organization has also issued guidance on the handling and handling of imported and exported seafood, including seafood products imported from the Schengen Area, which are being tested for the novel coronavirus. These products must be thoroughly washed and disinfected before being shipped to or from a country where the imported seafood is suspected of having been introduced into the international food supply chain. This is particularly important in countries that have been hit hard by the outbreak, such as the Philippines, where more than 200,000 people have died in the first three months of this year alone. WHO is assessing ongoing research on how to best use all of these measures to protect the health and well-being of people living with HIV/AIDS and their families, while also ensuring that the protection of essential public health services is maintained and that international travel is conducted in a manner that is consistent with international law and does not compromise the rights and freedoms of health workers and other people. For more information, see WHO’s Guidance on International Travel and Contaminated Food and Agriculture: Guidance for Allowing Allocators and Overseas Citizens to Enter the United States of America, The Global Entry and Residence Restrictions on Entry of Certain Entry-Permitted Nationals (GISPR) for Certain Countries (GISSPR-2006), International Travel Rules for Certain Nationals (Joint Declaration on Protection of International Health and Medical Workers) and Organizations and Clerical Committees on Immunization, Respiratory and Critical Care Services (CARES-C), and Related Public Health Security and Disaster Assistance (PHENDS) Act of 2020 (H.R.2201), as amended (Public Law 107–291; 128 Stat. 1287; 20 U.S.C. 2301 et seq.).

What is the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones from COVID-2019 and other viruses?

This is a rapidly evolving area, and there are many different approaches that are being considered. Some of these are:


Regularly clean your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds after touching your face, nose or mouth;
Avoid touching objects or surfaces that may be in contact with you, such as tables, countertops, lamps, washing machines, light switches, etc.;
Wear disposable gloves when handling animals, including hand sanitizers and hand rubs.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or tissue soaked in warm, water or soap. If possible, cover your mouth and nose with an alcohol-based tissue before, during and after your visit to a doctor or other medical facility, to help protect you and others from the virus. (See CDC’s Tips for Wash Your Hands for more information on how to safely clean and disinfect surfaces and objects.)
Practice social distancing (e.g., using the same bathroom and changing facilities twice a day) and frequent handshakes with family members and friends, especially if they are ill or have other health conditions that limit their ability to interact with others. Avoid touching personal protective equipment (PPE) that is not on hand when you are away from home, as this can increase the risk of infection and could compromise your health and well-being (see How to Avoid Infections and Illnesses from Hands and PPE in the Public Health Chaplaincy of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Managing Illness and Well-Being from Personal Protection Equipment in Public and Community Settings: A Guide for Preparing for Health Care Professionals and Their Families at Home and at Work?, American Society of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, vol. 62, no. 2, p. 543-547, published online March 27, 2020).

The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to be mainly transmitted through droplets expelled from a person coughing or sneezing.

However, the World Health Organisation (WHO) has said that it is not yet certain whether the coronavirus is spread through contact with bodily fluids or through contaminated food or drink.


So far, there is no evidence to suggest that people are more vulnerable to the disease if they have been exposed to it through food, drink or other means. However, WHO is advising people to wash their hands frequently and avoid touching their eyes, nose or mouth, as well as their nose and mouth when they are ill or sick. This is particularly important for pregnant women and young children, who are at higher risk of developing severe illness if their body is damaged during pregnancy and childbirth, according to WHO. The risk is also higher for people of all ages, including those with underlying health conditions, and those who have recently lost their jobs, such as those at public health, fire, police and ambulance services. It is therefore important to regularly clean your hands, cover your cough with the bend of elbow or tissue and maintain a distance of at least 1 metre (3 feet) from people you are close to. If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance. Follow the directions of your local health authority and local authorities for any restrictions on travel, movement or movement of people or goods. WHO advice on how to protect yourself and others is available on the WHO website and can be found on its official website. For more information, see WHO’s Guidance on Travel and Other Contaminated Public Health Concerns and How to Protect Yourself and Others in the 21st Century.<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

There is no evidence that the coronavirus can be transmitted from person to person via droplets expelled from the nose or mouth. However, there is a possibility that some people may have acquired the virus through exposure to infected surfaces. This is why it is important to wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds after touching a surface. If you do not have any symptoms, use alcohol-based hand rub (see How to clean hands for more information).
If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention immediately. Call in advance and inform your healthcare provider if you are feeling unwell. Follow the directions of your local health authority and local government and provide information about how to safely carry out hand hygiene activities in your home. <|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that includes the common cold, influenza, parainfluenza, rabies, and many more.  

The virus that causes COVID-19 is called the "common cold".  It is thought to cause about 80% of the world's colds, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).  However, the virus can cause serious illness in people who are not exposed to it, including people with underlying medical conditions, such as heart disease, cancer, diabetes, lung disease or other chronic conditions. The WHO estimates that between 1.5 and 2.6 million people worldwide are at risk of developing severe illness from the 2019-nCoV outbreak, which has killed more than 2,000 people in the U.S., China, India, Pakistan, Iran, Singapore, Japan, South Korea and the Philippines. WHO is assessing ongoing research to understand the full extent of human-to-human transmission, as well as the extent to which new infections are being identified and managed. For more information on the current outbreak in your area, please click here.

xt|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

What is the current status of the coronavirus in China and how can I protect myself against it and prevent the spread of it to my family and friends and family members? 


I am a Chinese citizen living in Hong Kong. My wife and I live in a major city in mainland China. We have two young children who are in elementary school and middle school.  
We have been in contact with a number of local health authorities, including the Ministry of Health, the People's Protection Committee and the Public Health Protection Office, all of which have advised us to stay indoors and away from other people, especially our elderly and people with underlying medical conditions, to reduce the risk of spreading the disease to our children and to avoid social distancing and other measures to protect ourselves and our loved ones from the potentially infectious disease. The government has also instructed health workers to regularly clean our homes and wash our hands with soap and water, as well as regularly disinfecting our cars and trucks with detergent and hand sanitizer when we are out in public. I am not aware of any restrictions on travel, movement or movement of people within China, nor have I been told that I can stay in hotels, restaurants, cinemas, shopping centres or other public places for the duration of my stay. However, I do not want my children to be in any danger, and have instructed them not to touch my face, nose or mouth with the use of alcohol-based hand rub or any other cleanser, lest they become ill or ill-preventing themselves from developing the illness. In addition, my wife is a citizen of China who has applied for a residence permit and is currently in her third year of secondary education, so she is not allowed to travel outside of her country of residence, except to visit her family or friends. She has not been to any major international sporting events, such as the Olympics, World Cups, Commonwealth Games, Diamond Jubilee, Olympics or Paralympic Games since her entry into China in January 2020. Her Chinese passport is valid until her application is approved by the relevant authorities and she has been issued a travel document, valid for at least 14 months, which she can return to China at any time, provided that she complies with all relevant local laws and regulations regarding her travel and her personal security and health. If she does not comply with these regulations, she will be subject to a fine of up to HK$600 (HK$1,200) for each violation of this regulation, or both, whichever is greater. This fine is in addition to the fine imposed on the person who intentionally causes the disruption of public order and public health by intentionally causing public disorder or endangerment of health or the health and safety of others by means of force majeure, fire, earthquake, tsunami, civil disturbance, disease or natural disaster. For more information on this matter, see How to Protect Yourself and Your Children from Coronaviruses and Protecting Yourself from Illness and Health from Illnesses in Public Area of China, World Health Organization Annual Report 2020-2020 (WHA), Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Guidance for Disaster Relief and Disaster Assistance (DIYDRDOJ), and Coordinated Disaster Preparedness Protection Strategy for Disaster Infectious Diseases (Diseases in which the life-threatening situation is expected to escalate into a state of emergency within a specified period of time within the next 14 days), the National Disaster Risk Assessment 2020 (NDPA) or DHS-CoV-2 Summary of Threats to the United States and its territories as of March 30, 2020, unless and until the Secretary of State submits to Congress a report detailing the situation in the affected country within that country within that 14 day period, within which such report shall be treated as public information and shall have the force of law effect as provided by section 505(a)(1)(B) of title 5, United  States Code, with respect to such country. Such guidance shall include the procedures for timely and accurate reporting of such information to Federal, State, local, tribal or territorial officials, health care providers, law enforcement and emergency response personnel, medical personnel of national or local government agencies and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and their designees as appropriate, in consultation with their local and territorial partners and with appropriate international and domestic stakeholders. Any such guidance may be adapted and updated in accordance

The virus that causes COVID-19 was first identified in Wuhan, China in 2003. Since then, it has spread widely throughout the world, with cases in China surpassing the number of cases reported in the United States in January.

However, the virus has not been able to completely eradicate the disease, and scientists are still trying to piece together how it spread. For example, in a recent study, scientists found that a virus can survive on surfaces for up to 14 days on copper, a material that is commonly used in hand sanitizers. However, that does not mean that it cannot also be transmitted through respiratory droplets produced when someone coughs or sneezes into a tissue, or through the skin of a person who has recently been infected. Instead, researchers believe that this type of transmission is likely to occur through contact with an infected person's bodily fluids, which is why it is important to regularly clean and disinfect surfaces around the body, including the mouth and nose, as well as the eyes, nose and mouth. The World Health Organization (WHO) has also issued guidance to health care workers on how to safely dispose of body fluids and personal protective equipment (PPE) when they are ill, sick or in need of medical attention.


  “It’s very difficult to predict how this virus will spread,” said Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Coordination at the George Washington University School of Public Health. But, he cautioned against "running around like a chicken with no legs."  "If you have a fever, cough and difficulty breathing, you're probably going to get sick," he said. "But if you get a cold and have no symptoms at all, chances are you'll be fine. If you develop symptoms, call your doctor and ask to have your temperature checked and your blood pressure checked. That way you don't have to go to the emergency room and get tested again." The WHO recommends that people wash their hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds before touching their face or hands, before eating or taking any medications or using the bathroom, to help protect themselves and others. And wash your hands frequently with alcohol-based hand rub, such as W.R.W. or Ethyl alcohol if soap is not readily available.  
 But there is still a lot that remains unknown about the true extent of human-to-human transmission. WHO is working to develop a vaccine and is encouraging people to share their findings with the public, so that they can make informed decisions about whether to travel to or stay at a health facility where they may have been exposed.<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

The main way that coronavirus spreads is through respiratory droplets expelled by someone who is coughing or sneezing. This is why it is important to wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds before touching your face, nose or mouth. If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance. Follow the directions of your local health authority and local authorities to ensure that you are not in contact with anyone who has been exposed to COVID-19 and is thought to be in the same category as others who have been diagnosed with the disease. WHO is advising people to stay at home and away from people they are close to, including their children and pregnant women, as they can be at higher risk for severe illness and poorer outcomes. For more information on how to protect yourself and your loved ones, visit: https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronaviruses/2019-ncov/about/how-to-protect-yourself/stay-at-home-and-away-from-other-people-who-have-been-infected/advice-for-public-health-persons/what-can-you-do/ [PDF]
How can I protect myself and my family? Visit WHO’s Manage Your Health and Wellbeing website to find out how you can reduce your risk of developing a range of health problems including:Regular physical activity and regular exercise are good ways to help keep you physically and mentally healthy.Regular exercise can also help protect you from viruses and other respiratory infections, such as colds and flu. You should also take good care to cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or tissue covering when you exercise or go to a park or exercise area. Talk to your health care provider about any changes in your routine and ensure they take into account your current health condition and the risk you may have for any of the following:High blood pressure, heart or lung disease, diabetes, cancer or any other chronic conditions.If you develop any symptoms, call your healthcare provider and tell them you're experiencing symptoms and are taking medicines to manage your symptoms.You should start taking provisional anti-inflammatories (such as ibuprofen, naproxen or aspirin) every 3-5 days and continue taking them for 14 days after symptoms start to improve. These medicines should only be taken once a day, and you should not take any more than one of these medicines at a time.<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

The best way to protect yourself and others from COVID-19 is to regularly clean your hands, cover your cough with your bent elbow or tissue and maintain a distance of at least 1 meter (3 feet) from people who are coughing or sneezing. If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance. Follow the directions of your local health authority and local authorities, including local guidance on how to stay safe and stay home if you are in contact with someone who is sick or has been to a public health facility. Stay aware of the local restrictions on travel, movement and movement of people, as well as any restrictions that may apply to people coming from outside your country of residence. You should also be aware that you should not touch your face, nose, mouth or eyes, or carry any other personal items that could pose a risk to you or others. For more information about how your health and safety are managed, visit WHO’s Manage Your Health and Safety website.<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

What is the current status of the WHO-CoV-2 ban in the UK and Ireland, as well as the restrictions imposed by the European Union on travel from the Schengen Area to other EU member states, including the Czech Republic, Hungary, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland?


The current situation is that the ban has been in place for 14 days in all EU Member States, except for the Republic of Ireland. It is therefore not yet possible to travel to, or visit, the affected countries without a visa. However, it is possible for a visitor to enter the EU from another Member State (e.g. France, Germany, Italy, Austria, Belgium, etc.), but this is not possible due to Article 25(1)(b) of Regulation (EU) No 1094/2004 of 28 March 2020. The ban does not apply to non-EU citizens who are citizens of a third country, i.e., citizens or permanent residents of another EU State. 
However, there is no restriction on the number of people who can enter or leave the country at any given time. For example, a person who is travelling from a country outside of its borders to a member state in order to visit a child care facility in another member State may be able to do so, but only if the facility is closed for reasons other than the visitor's personal safety or the need for medical care. This is because the purpose for which the travel is conducted is to provide a means of transit, not to prevent or hinder the entry or transit of individuals who pose a risk of serious harm to health and the safety of others. Therefore, for purposes of paragraph 1(a)(ii)(B), the prohibition on entry is limited to persons who have been "visibly ill" for at least 6 months and who "are not otherwise physically present in a public health facility".
For the reasons set out in paragraph 2(b)(i)(I), this restriction is inapplicable only to travellers who meet criteria of "non-credible threat". For this reason, no restrictions are imposed on nationals of EU countries who do not meet the criteria for this purpose, nor on visitors from countries that are not in compliance with this ban.

There are a few things you can do to help your child stay calm and focused during the day, such as:


Practice social distancing (self-monitoring, socialising, etc)
Try to avoid social gatherings (e.g. pubs, cinemas, restaurants, bars etc.)
Use social media (Facebook, Twitter, Youtube) to communicate with family and friends
Take time to talk to people outside your home (children, teachers, co-workers, neighbours, friends, colleagues, schoolmates etc.).
Talk to your children about the news, movies, TV shows, music, games etc., and listen to what they are saying (listen to their favourite radio stations).
If possible, limit contact with people who are not in your household (parents, grandparents, grandparent, brother, sister, boyfriend, stepchildren...)
Set up a time of rest (no more than 20 minutes) between when you are away from others (30 minutes, up to 1 hour) and when they need to go to the doctor or other medical facility to get medical care (for example, if you have diarrhoea, cough or difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance).

Yes, but only if you’ve been exposed to it. 

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends washing hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, before touching any packaging or packaging materials, and after using it to cover your cough, sneeze or difficulty breathing. You can also use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer to treat common colds and other respiratory illnesses, the CDC says.
 But there is no evidence that touching a plastic bag increases the risk of catching the coronavirus, according to Dr. Anthony Fauci, a professor of microbiology and immunology at the University of California, Los Angeles. The virus can live on surfaces for days or even weeks on plastic and stainless steel, making it hard to pick it up from a trash can or discarded packaging. [See How to Wash Your Hands with Bleach](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/04/health/coronaviruse-how-to-wash-your-hand-with-bleach.html) and how to disinfect your hands after touching cardboard boxes, plastic containers and metal objects.


Soap, water and soap are all good ways to protect yourself from COVID-19. But what if someone touches your face, then spreads the virus to your eyes, nose or mouth? Or if a person sneezes on your clothes? And if soiled clothes are anything to go by, how do you know if they are safe to leave in the back of the vehicle?

Yes, isolation is a good idea. But it’s not the only way to protect yourself from COVID-19.

Studies in China found that people with mild symptoms — such as fever, cough or shortness of breath — were more likely to be infected with the virus than those with severe symptoms, according to a March study in the Journal of the American Medical Association. And in a study of more than 100,000 people in Wuhan, China, about half of those who tested positive for the coronavirus were hospitalized, the study found.


So why do some people (like yourself) take antiviral medicine to help manage their symptoms? Well, some studies suggest that some types of medications — like ibuprofen, naproxen or hydroxychloroquine — may be effective in some patients, but they're not as effective as others in others, and they can cause side effects that can lead to serious illness. For example, people who are taking antiretrovirals (such as flu shot and corticosteroids) may not be as well-prepared for severe illness as other people, so they may take them at higher doses, which can increase the risk of serious complications, including heart disease, stroke, cancer and diabetes.  
 But there are some things you can do to reduce your chances of catching the disease from someone who is not taking any of these medications. First, wash your hands often with soap and water. Then, cover your mouth and nose with your bent elbow or tissue when you cough, sneeze or feel unwell. Follow the directions of your local health authority, tell your doctor or pharmacist and talk to your health care provider about any changes you may have to make, especially if you have fever or other symptoms. If you develop fever and are concerned about how your symptoms are progressing, seek medical attention and call in advance, said Dr. William Schaffner, a professor of neurology and immunology at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine and the author of a recent book on the topic, The Best of Emergencies: How to Protect Yourself From the 2019-nCoV. (Harvard Medical School Press, 2016).

Antibiotics are a group of drugs that are used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections. The most commonly used antibiotics are penicillins, lopinavir, and metronidazole. 

However, there are some studies that suggest that some antibiotics may not work as well as they should. For example, one study found that ibuprofen caused pneumonia in patients with severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (SARS-CoV-2), but did not show any benefit for other types of antibiotics. Other studies have shown that corticosteroids may be ineffective against COVID-19, but these studies were limited to patients who had no underlying medical conditions and were not taking antiretrovirals (e.g., steroids). 


  In the current study, we show that, despite the lack of benefit of any of the antibiotics used for pneumonia prevention and treatment, the use of cortics was associated with a significant reduction in the incidence of pneumonia among patients treated with either the flu or the pneumococcal conjunctivitis vaccine (PCV). These results are in line with previous studies on the effectiveness of different antibiotics in treating pneumonia. However, these results do not rule out the possibility of side effects, such as fever, cough, or shortness of breath. These findings are consistent with the results of a recent study that evaluated the efficacy of flu-vaccine combination drugs in preventing and treating SARS and MERS in children.
The study results also support the importance of using appropriate antiviral therapies to prevent and treat common infections, including those caused by influenza and related respiratory diseases. This is particularly important for those who are immunocompromised, as these patients are at higher risk for severe illness and poorer outcomes from complications from the common cold and other respiratory conditions. 
In conclusion, while there is currently no evidence that any antibiotic is or can prevent or treat pneumonia infection, it is possible to use a combination of certain antibiotics to reduce the risk of infection and improve outcomes in a variety of settings. In particular, antibiotics should not be used as a means of prevention or treatment of influenza, nor are they intended to replace or replace the health care system. Rather, they are an important means by which the public and health authorities can better protect themselves and their loved ones against the most serious threats to public health and the well-being of those living with or caring for them.<|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

There is no known risk of transmission of COVID-19 from pet food to humans. However, it is important to wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds after handling a pet animal.

If you are concerned about your pet's health or wellbeing, you should seek medical attention immediately. If you have symptoms, call your local health authority and ask them to provide you with medical advice. You can also call in advance to report symptoms to the local authorities. For more information on how to protect yourself and protect your family, see How can I protect myself and my family? What is the best way to protect yourself and others against COVID-19 in the 21st century?

The CDC has a list of things you can do to reduce your risk of catching the virus.  Some of these are as simple as washing your hands often and avoiding touching your eyes, nose or mouth. You can also try to stay away from people who are coughing or sneezing, or people with underlying medical conditions, such as heart disease, diabetes, cancer or cancer of the lungs. But there are also important things to keep in mind:


Stay home if you feel unwell.
Avoid close contact with others, especially if they are ill or have a history of other health problems, like high blood pressure, high cholesterol, heart or lung disease. If you develop fever, cough or difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance. Avoid social gatherings and gatherings with other people, including going to a park or hiking, and limit outdoor playdates and outdoor activities. Follow the directions of your local health authority (CDC) and local laws and regulations. Don’t leave your vehicle unless you are physically present with someone who is sick or needs to be isolated. Travel to and from work, school, religious, recreational or cultural events, as well as from places with high transmission rates (e.g., airports, railway stations, shopping centres, sports stadiums, ski resorts and other public facilities). 
Practice social distancing and regular hand hygiene when you travel. This includes handshakes, hand rubs and hand washing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, before and after each trip, to help stop the spread of illness and protect others from possible infection. Do not touch your face or clothes. Why? Wearing face coverings can increase the chance that you may be infected and can make you susceptible to other viruses. For more information, see How much contact should you make with your health care provider? How much physical contact do you need to make to get the infection under control? What kinds of precautions should be taken to prevent the transmission? CDC recommends everybody wear a face mask when out in public, in groups or in designated areas. Regularly, carry a medical mask with you whenever you go out to exercise, go to the park, visit a doctor or other designated health facility, take a walk or cycle between work and play, avoid public transportation and use public transit. Use hand sanitizer and soap to wipe down any dirt or debris that may have accumulated on your mask before you leave the facility. And remember: Always use a mask to cover the mouth and nose, not the chin or elbow. When you cough, sneeze or feel ill, use an inhaler to relieve pressure on the mask, which can be inhaled or absorbed by the skin or mucus membranes. Always wash hands before, during or after any contact to people you know or care for. WHO has also published guidance on the use of face masks for people living with HIV and anyone with suspected or confirmed 2019-nCoV infection in the WHO Guidancebook for Healthcare Professionals and World Health Organization (WHO) Managing HIV/AIDS: A Call to Action for All People Living With HIV (MOHOG): Use Face Mask to Protect Yourself and Others from the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (NCTV) Spread and Recovered by Public Health Service Workers (PHSEW) in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China, on March 27, 2020 (Public Health Agency of China).  This is a global public health emergency and requires all countries to take extraordinary measures to contain and contain the outbreak. The WHO recommends all countries begin to implement precautionary measures based on evidence and evidence-based practice, including public health awareness and assessment of the risk from COVID‑19 and the need for co-ordinated, rapid and sustained response. To learn more about WHO guidance on hand hygiene visibly clean your hands with a disinfectant that is safe and effective for you and your person(s). WHO is working with partners and stakeholders to develop a stronger, more effective and cost-effective approach to this critical pandemic. In addition, WHO will continue to work with health authorities around the world to ensure the protection of their populations, their health systems and their communities through coordinated and continuous ensure that all people have access to essential health services and that their health immunity is sufficient to meet the highest standards of quality and quantity.    WHO works with governments and non-governmental organizations to identify, develop, implement and disseminate best practices for all levels of government to support the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of all types of infectious diseases

The main difference between the two is that people who have been exposed to the virus in the past few days are more likely to develop symptoms of the disease.

For example, a person who has been infected with SARS-CoV-2 for 14 days in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China, tested positive for the coronavirus. He had been in contact with a relative who had recently returned from a trip to China. The relative had visited the US recently, and the relative was visiting a family member who was also recently infected.  In the current outbreak, this relative is thought to be the first person in China to have developed symptoms, which is why it is important to monitor the health care workers who are treating the patients in their care.

The main way the virus spreads is through respiratory droplets produced by a person coughing or sneezing. This is why it is important to wash your hands frequently with soap and water after using the bathroom, before eating, and before going to the grocery store. The stimulus package includes $1.5 trillion in stimulus payments to states and localities, as well as $500 billion in loans to help pay for essential services, including food stamps, unemployment insurance, and the Children's Health Insurance Program. But it also includes a provision to extend unemployment benefits for up to six months to people who have lost their job due to the coronavirus outbreak. And it includes an additional $600 billion for the Pell Grants, which help families with pre-existing medical conditions receive aid.  

But there's a catch. If you've lost your job, you can apply for unemployment through your state or local agency. That means you'll have to wait until April 15 to get your check. The deadline for applying for a new job is April 30, but some states have already extended their deadline. So if you don't qualify, your application could be delayed or you could get kicked out of the program. You can still get the stimulus check, though, if your employer offers it to you instead of your ex or ex-spouse. It's unclear how much of that money will go toward helping people get back on their feet, or whether it will be used for other purposes, like paying for medical care or other essential needs. Some states are also offering job training programs, some of which are aimed at older adults and people with disabilities. [The Washington Post]
 [More from The Hill: How President Trump's travel ban affected the economy](https://www.thehindep.com/story/news/politics/2020/03/27/donald-trump-travel-ban-affected-economy/5078653001/)
The Hill has more: 


  “It’s a good idea to think ahead,” said Michael Froman, a professor at Georgetown University's School of Global Public Health who has spent his career studying the effects of economic shocks on the U.S. and global health system. ‘If you look at the stock market, for example, the S&P 500 has gone from strength to strength in the last couple of years. They have been able to recover from the worst economic crisis since the Second World War and now they are in a stronger position than ever before to take risks and invest in things that are going to benefit them and help them grow. This is a very good time to be a risk taker and be prepared for what might come next. We need to have a plan in place to protect ourselves and our loved ones from this pandemic and protect the health and well-being of our children and grandchildren as much as we can. There is no doubt that the economic impact of this crisis will have an impact on our economy, our health care system, society and communities around the world.“
President Trump has ordered the Environmental Protection Agency to conduct a review of how it plans to clean up after the COVID-19 outbreak, to assess the risks posed by the virus and to make recommendations about how the agency can best protect itself and its communities. [...] The EPA has also instructed its employees to stay at home and clean surfaces with the use of hand sanitizer and other household cleaning products. EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt has instructed EPA employees not to touch personal protective equipment, such as masks, gloves and face coverings, unless it is necessary for work or personal use.
Trump's order also directs the EPA to begin issuing new guidance to businesses and individuals who are experiencing disruptions to their work, travel and business activities. Businesses are required to notify their employees and their family members by March 15, 2020, that they will no longer be allowed to work from 9 a.m. to midnight. Those employees are subject to a 15-day leave of absence order.

Coronavirus is a new virus that has been around since the beginning of time. It is thought to be mainly transmitted through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes.

However, there are many other viruses that cause respiratory infections including the common cold, influenza, dengue, rabies, rubella, Zika, and SARS. These viruses can cause serious illness and even death. Therefore, it is important to regularly clean your hands, cover your cough with the bend of elbow or tissue and maintain a distance of at least 1 meter (3 feet) from people you are close to. This means covering your mouth, nose and mouth with a tissue or cloth when you sneeze or cough. If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance. Follow the directions of your local health authority and local authorities to ensure the safety and well-being of everyone in your area. WHO is advising people to stay at home and away from others as much as possible, including their children and pregnant women. If you are worried about your child’s health or wellbeing, talk to them about the risks and benefits of social distancing.

If you have been in contact with someone who has been exposed to COVID-19, such as family members or close friends, it is important to ensure they have the information you need to make informed choices about how they can protect themselves and their loved ones. This information can be shared with the wider community and health authorities, and can include details of how the illness is managed, how symptoms are managed and when they begin to manifest. It can also include information on how to safely share personal information, including contact details, with people who may be at risk of developing or spreading the disease. You should also be aware that some local authorities may not be able to provide the same level of protection to everyone in your area, so you should consult with your local health authority to find out what additional measures are in place to help ensure everyone is safe and sound in relation to the spread of the coronavirus. For example, if you live in a major city or have a significant other's address, you may want to take extra precautions to avoid crowds, avoid public transport and avoid going out of your way to get close to people you know or care for. However, there are some important things to consider when deciding whether to move:


You should not leave your home to go out for a walk, jog or other activity that is likely to cause you or your loved one to become ill.  This includes:
Going to and from work, school and other public places,
Taking a short walk or bicycle ride (e.g. walking, cycling, walking on a designated path or trail, or using the public toilet or shared space)
Regularly and thoroughly cleaning your hands with a disinfectant or hand sanitiser
Keeping a distance of at least 1 metre (3 feet) between yourself and anyone who is coughing or sneezing
Avoid public gatherings and gatherings where people are mingling or sharing food, drink and personal items
Do not go to a restaurant, bar or takeaway unless absolutely necessary to cover your cough and sneeze with an alcohol-based hand rub or a tissue or tissue soaked with soap and water (if possible).  If your health condition worsens, seek medical attention and call in advance to arrange a medical appointment, rather than waiting for the results of a test or referral to an early-stage diagnostic test centre. Talk to your healthcare provider about any changes to their advice, particularly if they are based on the latest case numbers and the extent to which they believe the situation is stable and that they would be willing to work with you to support you in any way you can. If they do not have any available specialist advice for you, call them and ask them to advise you on your options. They will be happy to give you the most up-to-date information as soon as possible. To learn more, see What is the current situation in the UK and what is available to you? and What are the restrictions and restrictions on travel, movement and importation of people from outside the EU? The Home Office has advice on this and will continue to update it as new information becomes available. See Advice for people living with HIV and those with other chronic conditions How can I protect myself and my family? for more information about protecting yourself, your family and others from the virus. The Prime Minister “announced today that the Government will provide £1.5bn in emergency funding for communities affected by the outbreak,” which will help protect vulnerable people and help them access essential services and supplies. More information about the funding can ongov.uk/publications/funding-for-the-public-health-and-social-distancing-of-people-with- HIV/AIDS/2020/part-1/how-can-you-protect-self- and-your-family.html

I don't know about you, but I'd like to know if there are any studies which try to measure the effect of social distancing measures on people’s daily lives.  If so, what measures would you recommend to help people maintain social distance?  Or is there some other measure which can be used to reduce the risk of being infected by COVID-19, such as:
Regularly washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially if you are coughing or sneezing
Avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth with your bent elbow or tissue
Cover your cough with a tissue and throw it away
Wear a mask and carry it with you whenever you go out
If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance
Take care to cover your mouth and nose with an alcohol-based hand sanitizer (I use Hydroxychloroquine)
Practice hand hygiene and maintain good eye contact with people who are ill
Try to avoid public gatherings and gatherings where people congregate in groups (e.g. pubs, cinemas, restaurants, bars, clubs, etc.)
Consider postponing or slowing down trips to and from work, school, or other public places, as well as taking care not to touch your face, hands or face with objects that may be in your path
Stop going to the grocery store and buy groceries from a convenience store, and instead go to a fast-food restaurant and order a burger from there (if you can afford it, of course).
I'd also recommend taking a walk or bike ride every 15 minutes or so to get around and avoid crowds and traffic accidents. If you do this, you should aim to stay 6 feet away from anyone who is walking, biking or scurrying around, even if they are not in close proximity to you. You should also avoid crowded public transport, including buses, trains, planes and planes with passengers on board, so that you and your family can go wherever you need to go without having to worry about being bumped or swabbed by someone who might be passing them by. This will help keep you physically and mentally healthy while also reducing the chance of you getting sick and possibly exposing yourself to viruses that could be transmitted by others. I would also suggest staying up to date on all the latest news and information about the virus and how to protect yourself and others by following the links provided by the WHO and other WHO-recommended public health authorities. For example, here is a link to WHO's website: https://www.who.int/emergencies/public-health/diseases/2019-ncov/about/who-admits- 2019-novel-coronaviruses-in-the-community/how-to-protect-yourself-and- others/cdc/article/S1473-3099(20)30161-3/fulltext

What is the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones from the COVID-2019? (source: CDC)
The CDC has developed a list of things you can do to reduce your risk of catching the virus.  These include:
Regularly and thoroughly clean your hands with soap and water
Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth
Wear a mask when you are outside
Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or tissue
Take a swab from your nose or mouth and throw it in the trash
If you have fever, cough or difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance
Stay home if you feel unwell, stay home for at least 20 minutes, and avoid going to the doctor
Practice social distancing (self-isolation, isolation and isolation by phone, videochat, etc.)
Try to stay 2m (3ft) away from others, including family and friends
Talk with your doctor or other health care provider about any symptoms or concerns you may have, such as fever or a cough
Call your local health authority and ask them to take you to a doctor for a test or treatment
Consider postponing or cancelling trips to places you normally would have been able to go, or taking a bus or train to get to your place of work, school or clinic
Travel to and from work or school is a good idea, but it’s important to remember that you will not be allowed to leave your home unless absolutely necessary to care for someone else
Keep up to date with the latest news and information about the outbreak in your area, as well as any local coronavirus outbreaks
Monitor social media and news reports from affected areas to make sure they are not being used to disseminate information that could be harmful to you or others
Prepare meals and snacks that are safe to eat and are appropriate for children under the age of 5, to help them stay active and healthy
Have regular physical activity and maintain a regular distance from people who are ill or sick
Be active in school, work and recreational activities (such as running, cycling, hiking, swimming, yoga and other physical activities) that help you maintain physical and mental health
Encourage your children to play outside and play in parks and open spaces, especially playgrounds, so they can continue to learn about healthy ways to exercise and socialize


What are some of the recommendations for people living with HIV and those with other chronic conditions?  
How can I help protect myself and my loved one against the disease? What should I do if I suspect I may be at increased risk for serious illness or for having other serious health conditions that would seriously limit my ability to function in my current role as an educator, researcher, public health officer, health educator or researcher? Do I need to be on antiretrovirals (including the flu) or take any medicines? If so, what other preventive measures are there that I can take to prevent myself from developing any more severe illness and prevent others from contracting the infection? I would like to hear from anyone who has been in contact with someone who is currently or has recently been exposed to or is at higher risk to develop any of these conditions, whether or not they have HIV or are currently immunocompromised. I am interested in hearing what you think about these recommendations and what can be done to minimize their impact on your own health and well-being. No. The virus that causes COVID-19 can be passed from person to person through droplets from coughs or sneezes. It can also be transmitted through food or drink.

If you have a fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance. If you feel unwell, call your healthcare provider and explain that you are ill and need to be isolated. Call your local health authority and ask them to provide you with a medical certificate confirming your illness and any restrictions on travel, movement or movement of people. You should also wear a mask and carry a cloth face covering when out in public, to protect yourself and others from the virus.<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to be spread mainly through contact with respiratory droplets produced when someone coughs or sneezes.

However, the World Health Organisation (WHO) has said that it is not possible to know for certain how long a virus can survive on surfaces and is therefore not suitable for use as a vaccine.


The WHO says that: 
  “We do not know the full extent of human-to-human transmission,” the WHO said in a press release on Monday. It does not rule out the possibility of other viruses spreading from person to person, but it does advise that people should wash their hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds after touching a surface or object, before touching their eyes, nose or mouth and after eating or preparing food. People should also cover their mouths and noses with a tissue or tissue bag when they are ill, to stop the spread of the coronavirus. The WHO also recommends washing your hands often with alcohol or other hand sanitizer, as well as using alcohol-based hand rubs and hand hygiene products, such as wipes and toothbrushes. If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance, according to WHO guidance on how to care for people who are sick with or have severe symptoms, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute disseminated respiratory infection (AQI), and chronic respiratory disease (CQD). For more information, see WHO’s Guidance for People Living with HIV and How to Protect Yourself from HIV and HIV-CoV (part of The Early Phase of HIV/AIDS: A Global Overview and Assessment of Preparedness and Response for the 21st Century).
WHO is working with partners including the Australian, British and French governments to develop a rapid and reliable vaccine and to assess the safety and efficacy of existing vaccines. WHO will continue to share updated information on the progress of its efforts and will update this article when new information becomes available. To learn more about how WHO is assessing and developing vaccines, visit www.who.int/who-conducts-virus-vaccine-prevention-and-publication.html<|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

Yes, you should wear a mask to protect yourself and others from COVID-19.

CDC recommends wearing a cloth face covering when you are out and about, especially if you're visiting a medical facility. If you’re sick, cover your mouth and nose with your bent elbow or tissue when coughing or sneezing, and maintain a distance of at least 1 meter (3 feet) from others who are sick or ill. You should also wash your hands with soap and water after using the bathroom and before going to the doctor or receiving care, to stop the spread of the coronavirus.


  “If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance,” said Dr. Anthony Fauci, the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) chief.  But, he cautioned against using masks as a last-resort measure. The virus can survive on surfaces for days or weeks on hard surfaces, including cardboard, plastic and cardboard boxes. It can also be transmitted from person to person through droplets expelled from a person who has the virus. For most people, that means touching their eyes, nose or mouth. But some people can get the disease from touching objects or surfaces that are not their own, such as clothing, utensils and household items. And, if someone touches your face or hands, they may be at higher risk of catching the infection from someone else, according to a March 11, 2020 study in the journal Pediatrics. [See also: How to Wash Your Hands with Bleach](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/11/health/nyregion/how-to-wash-your-hand-with-britain-chloroquine.html) and this CDC post: Why Bleach Is a Good Place to Paint Your Face.]
And, for people who have recently become ill, wearing masks can be a good idea: The CDC recommends that people wear disposable medical masks, which can last up to two years in some cases. Other health organizations and medical professionals have also recommended that masks be reserved for health care workers and their families, as well as those with underlying medical conditions, like heart or lung disease or cancer patients who need to be hospitalized. Some states and local health departments are also encouraging people to wear masks for self-isolation and other nonmedical reasons, though that's not a recommended practice in most places, CDC officials say.<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endof We are currently in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, which has caused a global recession of over $100 billion.  

However, we are not alone in this situation, as many countries around the world are also experiencing severe shortages of essential services, including healthcare, essential medicines, and essential supplies such as medicines and medicines for the elderly and those with underlying medical conditions.


For example, the World Health Organization (WHO) has stated that the situation in China is "extremely critical", and that "the situation is expected to significantly worsen in coming weeks".  In other words, it is very likely that China will be forced to close its entire medical facilities in order to meet the WHO's stated goal of reducing the number of cases worldwide by as much as 40%.  This would be a major blow to the global health system as it would significantly increase the risk of further global pandemics, especially in countries with relatively low levels of infectious diseases like HIV/AIDS, malaria, tuberculosis and other chronic conditions like heart disease, stroke, diabetes, cancer, etc..  The WHO is also recommending that all countries work together to reduce their reliance on imported medical equipment and services (e.g. pumps, ventilators, blood banks, oxygen machines, electro-magnetic resonance spectrometers, ultrasound machines etc.), and to ensure that their existing systems are up to date and compliant with the latest standards of care and hygiene, to avoid unnecessary wastage of resources and unnecessary disruption to health systems and the health and well-being of people living with HIV and malaria patients. In addition, countries that have not yet implemented effective measures to contain the virus, or that are in a state of emergency, are likely to face significant economic, social and environmental costs as well as the potential for further economic and social disruption if they do not take decisive action to mitigate the risks posed by the current situation. This is particularly true in developing countries, where the impact on the economy and health of a country's response depends on how quickly and effectively the government intervenes to slow or halt the outbreak. For instance, in South Korea, a government shutdown in late January caused the country to lose more than $2 billion in economic output, while a nationwide lockdown in mid-March caused nearly $600 million in lost productivity and nearly a million people without access to basic services to begin to contract the disease. These are just a few examples of countries in which economic disruption could significantly impact the lives and livelihoods of millions of South Koreans and their affected communities. Governments should be prepared to respond to these situations by prioritizing the most vulnerable populations in their communities over those who are most at risk for serious illness and death. Countries should also take extraordinary precautions to protect themselves, their loved ones and others from the spread of COVID-2019. WHO has also issued guidance to all health care workers in affected countries to be on high alert for any signs of illness or a risk to themselves or others. It is therefore critical that they be aware of any possible travel restrictions, quarantine measures and/or other measures that may be put in place to limit their ability to travel to and from their country of residence. If you or someone you know is in close contact with a person who is seriously ill, for example by respiratory droplets or other bodily fluids, you should immediately call your local health authority immediately to make sure that you and your loved one are safe to go out and interact with others outside of your household. The most important thing you can do right now is stay home and avoid social gatherings and gatherings that could lead to direct contact between people who have been exposed to or have recently visited the affected area. You can find more information on WHO’s guidance on social distancing and contact tracing at: https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronaviruses/2019-ncov/community-distancing-guidance-for-public-health- workers-in-affected-countries/external-sites/default-source/docid/10.1016/j.jhin.2020.01.022 (accessed March 20, 2020).  For more on this topic, see WHO's Worldwide Guidance for Public Health Workers on Communicable Disease Communication and Disease Prevention and Control (WPDC) and How to Reduce the Risk of Infectious Disease and Related Conditions in the People, Groups and Institutions (P&G) Within a Health Care Facility (HCF) or Other Community-Based Facilities (CO

Talk to your healthcare provider about the situation and advise them whether you should cover your nose with a tissue or tissue from your hand, as this could increase the risk of catching the coronavirus. The coronavirus is a new virus that has not been seen in humans for more than a few months. It is thought to be mainly transmitted through respiratory droplets produced when a person coughs or sneezes. 

However, scientists are still trying to understand how this virus spreads and how it can cause illness. The World Health Organisation (WHO) has warned that the virus could cause serious illness in people up to 80 years of age and that people with underlying medical conditions, including heart disease, cancer and diabetes, should take extra precautions to protect themselves and their loved ones from COVID-19. WHO is advising people to stay at home and away from people they are close to, such as their children, their elderly or disabled family members, as well as those they have contact with. However, there is no evidence to suggest that any of these people are at higher risk of developing severe illness and death.


The WHO has also advised people not to touch their eyes, nose or mouth with their hands, and to avoid touching their face, which is covered in a thick covering called a “cloth” around their nose and mouth that covers their mouth and nose. People should also not carry any other personal items like a bag or purse with them or carry them around in their arms and legs, according to WHO. In addition, people should wear a mask when out in public and carry a medical thermometer (a device that measures temperature and relative humidity) in the back of their hand when walking, running or using the bathroom, a WHO statement said. [source: WHO](https://www.who.int/news-room/health/2020/03/20/coronaviruses-spread-through-the-world-health-organisations-and-how-to-keep-it-self-isolating-from-other-persons-during-travel-related-conditions-such-as-a-cough-or-sore-body-part-1?s=c&cid=2020-03-20-2020) to measure body temperature, humidity and other body-wide health measures, to help prevent respiratory infections and prevent the spread of respiratory diseases like colds and flu, among other things. For more information, see WHO’s Guidance for Health Professionals on Body Temperature and Humidity in Public and Public Health and How to Protect Yourself and Others from Illness and Illnesses. For information on how to maintain a healthy weight, See How to Keep Your Healthful In Public and Stay At Home for Regularly and Deductibly Wash Your Hands with a Cleaner Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, or use alcohol-based hand sanitizer if you are not sick or looking after someone who is. If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance. Follow the directions of your local health authority and local public health authorities for any local restrictions on travel, movement or movement of people or goods. The coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan, China, has caused widespread disruption to the lives of thousands of people. WHO is assessing ongoing efforts to contain the virus, and will continue to share updated findings as soon as they become available. 


The WHO has also issued guidance to healthcare workers and their healthcare providers about the risk of COVID-19 spreading to others. It advises that all people with suspected or confirmed 2019-nCoV infection should practice good respiratory hygiene, including washing hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, before touching the body of someone who has the disease. People should also wear a mask if they are in close contact with people who have the illness, such as a close-fitting cloth mask, a disposable medical mask or a face mask with a rubber band around the front of it. The WHO also advises people to wear cloth face coverings when out in public, especially at night, when people are ill or sick with other respiratory illnesses.
People should wear gowns and gown-like clothing to cover their noses and mouth, avoid touching their eyes, coughs, sneezes and difficulty breathing. Avoid touching your face, nose or mouth with your hands, as well as your bent elbow or tissue. Follow the directions of your local health authority and local authorities on how to protect themselves, their loved ones and the health of others who are at risk. No. The virus that causes COVID-19 is mainly spread through contact with respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes.

However, the World Health Organisation (WHO) has advised against touching your pet's mouth, nose or mouth with your hands, as this could expose the pet to potentially harmful respiratory viruses.


  A recent study in the journal PLOS One found that people who had been exposed to coronavirus had a significantly higher risk of developing a respiratory infection than did those who didn’t have the disease.  “The risk was higher among people with underlying medical conditions, including heart disease, cancer and diabetes,” said lead author Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, a professor of microbiology and immunology at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine and director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Control at Penn Medicine. But, he cautioned that pets should not be touched or carried around the house, especially if they are sick with a common cold or are immunocompromised. "If you have a sore throat, cough or difficulty breathing, pet owners should be on the lookout for ways to protect themselves and their loved ones from the potentially infectious virus," he told LiveScience.com. [See How Coronaviruses Spread](https://www.live.sciencemag.org/article/10.1126/science.aaa03665a) and other health care workers have been instructed to stay at least 6 feet away from pets that are in close contact, such as their owners, their family and others, and to wash their hands with soap and water before and after each visit, according to the WHO. In addition, people should avoid touching their eyes or nose, mouth or eyes, or their nose without a mask or other medical mask before going to a doctor or visiting a petting machine, said the study, which was funded by the National Institutes of Health (grants R01MH08953, R00MH07906 and R03MH09081).  [Read More: Why Is Petting So Hard to Protect Your Pets?, by Alex Dobuzinskas.]
 [MORE: What Are The Best Pet Care Products For Pets And How Can I Help Protect Myself? By Nicole Perlman, Ph.D., M.P.H. | Published March 27, 2020 | doi: 10.1093/pnas.160973-3099(20)30159-X | | CrossRef Full Text | Google Scholar
Oliver Gostin, MD, PhD, is the Chief Medical Officer of PetLife, Inc., a global leader in pet care products and services. He is also the founder and president of The Royal Veterinary College of Canada. Oliver has also authored several peer-reviewed medical journals.   “We’re going to do everything we can to help people,” Prime Minister Dominic Raab said in a televised address on Monday. He said the government would continue to provide support to vulnerable people and would work with local authorities to ensure they get the support they need.
